Award.AwardTitle: OP: Ultrafast and Optomechanical Properties of Individual Plasmonic Antennas

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Title: Understanding the energy relaxation pathways in optical antennas made from assemblies of metal nanoparticles

Non-Technical Description
Metal nanoparticles support the collective motion of their conduction band electrons in response to incident light, an effect known as a surface plasmon resonance. When those nanoparticles approach each other to within distances of less than their diameters, the surface plasmons start to couple just like connected harmonic oscillators, making it possible to engineer the overall optical response and design antennas that operate in the visible frequency range in complete analogy to radio frequency receivers and transmitters. The difference to radio antennas is that the dimensions are reduced to tens of nanometers (10-9 meter). While this concept of plasmon coupling and its use to receive and transmit radiation is fairly well understood, our understanding of heating losses (i.e. Ohmic resistance), which always occur in metals and are even more important in nanoparticles interacting with visible light, is limited for assemblies of nanoparticles with specifically designed plasmon resonances. This project aims to address this question and to provide detailed insight into how the overall geometry of the nanoparticle antenna affects the energy relaxation of absorbed photons that eventually produce heat by directly following the fate of the excitation energy with very short laser pulses. The knowledge gained through this work will make it possible to potentially minimize heating losses, but also and more importantly exploit the dependence of the energy relaxation dynamics on the antenna geometry to design fast opto-electronic switches and modulators.

Technical Description
The goal of this proposal is to determine the effect of the geometry of antennas made from different arrangements of metal nanoparticles that have various sizes and shapes on the electron-phonon coupling and acoustic vibrations. Specifically, the proposed project will address the following two objectives: (1) Establish the dependence of electronic energy relaxation on the nanoparticle antenna geometry and the type of the excited surface plasmon mode; and, (2) Investigate the mechanism for the excitation and damping of acoustic vibrations of strongly coupled nanoparticle antennas. To accomplish these goals, electron microscopy will be combined with single-particle transient extinction spectroscopy employing wavelength tunable pulses to investigate the same individual nanoparticle antennas. Single-particle spectroscopy techniques are necessary to correlate the optical and structural properties of individual nanoparticles antennas having different geometries because especially the damping of the acoustic vibrations is otherwise determined by extrinsic factors, i.e. nanoparticle size polydispersity. It is expected that the outcomes of the proposed studies will yield a detailed insight into how the structural parameters of a nanoparticle antenna, including the surrounding medium, can be engineered to optimize desired electron-phonon relaxation times and how impulsively launched acoustic vibrations can be exploited to modulate the optical signal from the antenna itself as well as quantum emitters located in the antenna gaps. These research efforts will lead to important contributions toward understanding the relationship between the ultrafast energy relaxation dynamics and the structure dependent collective plasmon modes in nanoparticle antennas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nanostructured materials are becoming increasingly popular in multiple areas of current technology. This NSF award, titled “Ultrafast and Optomechanical Properties of Individual Plasmonic Antennas”, was funded to investigate the ultrafast relaxation dynamics of isolated and coupled nanoantennas following optical excitation. Strong light absorption by metallic nanostructures at the plasmon resonance, the coherent oscillation of conduction band electrons, impulsively heats the nanoantenna when using ultrafast laser pulses. With a second, time delayed laser pulse this heating and the subsequent cooling dynamics can be followed in an all-optical manner, including the launching of mechanical breathing modes and their decay. The results of this research point toward the possibility of exploiting the nanoantenna mechanical properties for sensing ultralow mass changes.

 

Plasmons of neighboring nanostructures can couple to form new hybridized modes that depend on the overall geometry of the nanoparticle cluster. In particular, nanoantenna spacings and relative orientations for anisotropic shapes determine the coupling strength. To understand the factors that influence plasmon coupling, single-particle spectroscopy techniques are typically employed together with electron imaging to correlate optical properties with cluster geometry. However, how plasmon coupling affects the ultrafast relaxation dynamics in coupled nanoantennas was not well understood at the start of this project, especially since previous studies have reported contradicting results. The goal of this project was therefore to determine how cluster geometry affects the relaxation dynamics including mechanical breathing modes following ultrafast laser excitation.

 

To accomplish this goal we first advanced single-particle ultrafast microscopy at high laser repetition rates and hence low pulse energies, which are needed to avoid photothermal melting of metallic nanostructures, resulting however in limited wavelength tunability. We overcame this issue by generating wavelength tunable probe pulses in a photonic crystal fiber. Correlated electron microscopy and electromagnetic modeling aided in the interpretation of the spectroscopic signals. A major outcome of this instrument development was the ability to probe specific hybridized plasmon modes supported by different nanoantenna clusters.

 

With the help of this tool we characterized the coupling of mechanical breathing modes in a cluster of nanoantennas. Specifically, we found that the coupling induces frequency shifts in the breathing modes and that their magnitude depends on the interparticle spacing. This mechanical coupling is facilitated by the substrate, on which the nanostructures are placed. Furthermore, the decay of the breathing modes is dominated by the crystallinity of the metal, independent of the type of metal, as we observed similar behavior for gold and aluminum nanostructures. The study of aluminum nanoantennas is important because aluminum’s earth abundance allows for a sustainable approach to plasmonic nanostructure applications.

 

This NSF award supported research activities for 3 graduate students and 2 postdoctoral researchers and yielded 10 publications. Those involved have had the opportunity to learn sophisticated optical single-particle techniques, data analysis, nanostructure fabrication, and electromagnetic modeling as well as carry out collaborative research, present their results at local and national conferences, and publish in peer-reviewed journals. The results of these studies are significant because of their potential for developing highly sensitive methods to sense small mass changes in an all-optical manner by taking advantage of impulsively launched mechanical breathing modes.
